channel.title: ü™¥ Second Brain on
channel.description: Recent content in ü™¥ Second Brain on

item.title: Backtesting
item.description: Backtesting is the art of testing the performance of a strategy on historical data. While the platforms for backtesting are quite numerous, the most popular languages used are either python or C#.

item.title: Trading
item.description: Trading the financial markets is a very broad topic that encompasses all activities that lead to taking a trade in the financial markets.

item.title: Arch linux
item.description: Arch Linux. What can I say! I have been familiar with it, and pacman for such a long time, it feels like my oldest stable relationship.

item.title: C#
item.description: I never thought I’d enjoy writing C# because of an older aversion to what it represented especially in the world of microsoft.

item.title: Functional programming
item.description: Functional programming (FP) is a style of programming that relies on the creation of atomic, immutable functions, as opposed to relying on classes such as in object oriented programming.

item.title: i3
item.description: i3 (more specifically i3-wm or i3-gaps) is a tiled window managed. With a single hotkey, I split the screen in half either vertically or horizontally.

item.title: Installing Arch linux on WSL
item.description: Install Arch linux under WSL is quite straightforward. Head over to ArchWsl and download the latest version Extract the file Launch a terminal (I highly recommend windows terminal) cd into the location of the arch.

item.title: Javascript
item.description: Back in 2010, I argued about using javascript to rAun a node server (an option that was not popular at the time) because I wanted to learn one language to rule them all ü§ü

item.title: Programming
item.description: I have been writing code for over a decade. Giving you an exact number of years would reveal my age, and I am too shy to do that at that stage üòÜ

item.title: Quantower
item.description: Quantower (QT) is an all-in-one trading platform that connects to traditional brokers as well as crypto exchanges. It displays traditional OHLC charts, as well as advanced onces such a renko or range bars.

item.title: Ramda
item.description: Ramda is a Javascript library that emphasizes on writing pure Functional programming. It takes a moment to understand the power and beauty of using it, especially that its patterns are different than usual.

item.title: React
item.description: I have been programming the web for over a decade now, and I saw how front end frameworks evolved from jQuery, to backbone, ember, angular, and finally React and vue.

item.title: Running arch with i3 in wsl using vcxsrv
item.description: The goal of this post is to show a minimal configuration to run i3 in Arch linux under WSL using vcxsrv.

item.title: Typescript
item.description: Typescript is a strongly typed, object oriented, compiled language build on top of javascript. Below that fantastic mental breain-tease, what this means is that with typescript and tools such as the tsserver, programing is taken to a next level with smart auto-completion, intellisense, and renaming.

item.title: VcXsrv
item.description: VcXsrv is an X-server for windows. It allows WSL users to run a full fledge GUI system under linux. Note that with wslg, it became possible to run single GUI apps as if they were windows app.

item.title: Vim
item.description: Vim is probably one of the oldest text editors there is, rivaled only by eMacs. What distingues it from any other editor is that it places the user in different modes.

item.title: WSL
item.description: WSL stands for Window subsystem for linux. After struggling for years with dual-booting, and running linux on inefficient VM’s, I finally find myself able to run a full fledge linux distro from the comfort of my windows machine.

item.title: Dharma
item.description: In buddhism, the Dharma is teaching of the Buddha. It is the core of the buddhist philosophy. I perceive the dharma as the sign posts helping the meditators on the path.

item.title: Equanimity
item.description: Equanimity is the quality of remaining calm, still, and at peace, in the face of extreme adversity and suffering. It is a quality that a meditator cultivates over hours of sitting on the cushion, training the mind to see the rise and fall of emotional waves, and then learning how to not give into them.

item.title: Impermanence
item.description: Impermanence is one of the core buddhist doctrines. It means that nothing last and everything fades away. Emotions, events, and thoughts are like waves, constantly rising and falling in our experiences.

item.title: Insight (VipassanƒÅ)
item.description: VipassanƒÅ is a buddhist term that means insight. It is described as one of the two qualities that develop during the training of the mind.

item.title: Metacognitive Introspective Awareness
item.description: Metacognitive introspective awareness is essentially the cognition of being aware of your own cognition. To break the 3 words down:

item.title: Mindfulness
item.description: Mindfulness meditation is the practice of bringing one’s attention in the present moment back to the breath. Over, and over, and over again.

item.title: The 3 jewels
item.description: In Buddhism, a meditator is invited to take refuge in the 3 jewels which are: The Dharma The Buddha The Sangha The Dharma is the theoretical map of the Path that each meditators explores on the way to awakening.

item.title: The Four Noble Truths
item.description: The Four Noble Truths is the heart of the Buddhist doctrine. It is not to be believed blindly, but rather, it is an invitation to try and see for oneself.

item.title: The Path
item.description: In Buddhism, the path is the name given to the journey of the meditators as they grow from novice to adapt.

item.title: Th√≠ch Nh·∫•t H·∫°nh
item.description: Th√≠ch Nh·∫•t H·∫°nh was a zen buddhist Vietnamese monk who becamse famous after Martin Luther King Jr nominated him for the Nobel peace price for his effort to promote peace in war torn Vietnam.

item.title: Vipassana Meditation
item.description: The goal of Vipassana meditation Awakening, liberation, or cessation. It is achieved by: Establishing mindfulness and calming the mind 1.

item.title: üìö The Mind Illuminated
item.description: The mind illuminated (TMI) is among the first books I read in 2017 when I discovered Buddhism. It is a comprehensive encyclopedia of the challenges, theory, and techniques that a meditator needs on The Path.

item.title: Awakening
item.description: Awakening is a process where the mind ‘wakes up’ to the objective reality of its present experience. In buddhism, the end goal is awakening, also known as enlightenment.

item.title: Meditation
item.description: Meditation is a process, the systematic training of the mind. Let’s first define the scope of this training: Goal(s): The goal is awakening, or enlightenment.

item.title: Meditation is not about becoming a monk
item.description: I consider meditation to be the art of systematically training the mind üß†. The goal is to make it effortless for me to react to events in life.

item.title: Losing what is dear
item.description: The feeling that my unhappiness was coming from me not seeing girls or friends, is because, in reality, I was facing other problems, and in order to release the pressure and tension, I wanted to use the ways I have used so far to deal with stress: Sex, video games, and junk food.

item.title: The 8-fold path
item.description: The 8-fold path is the 4th noble truth in the The Four Noble Truths. It consists of 8 practices: Right view Right resolve Right speech Right conduct Right livelihood Right effort Right mindfulness Right concentration I struggled for a long time with the usage of the word Right, until I finally understood that it wasn’t about right or wrong in an absolute way.

item.title: A solution to the Paradox of Desire in Buddhism
item.description: seeing that there is no way out of the paradox of desire, under-standing that, as Madhyamika Buddhism puts it, there is no way to nirvana, no goal to be desired or achieved, then one “lets go” of the way and the goal.

item.title: A solution to the Paradox of Desire in Buddhism
item.description: seeing that there is no way out of the paradox of desire, under-standing that, as Madhyamika Buddhism puts it, there is no way to nirvana, no goal to be desired or achieved, then one “lets go” of the way and the goal.

item.title: Emptiness
item.description: Source: http://www.accesstoinsight.org/lib/authors/thanissaro/integrityofemptiness.html Wisdom on all levels is wise because it works, and to work, it requires integrity: the willingness to look honestly at the results of your actions, to admit when you’ve caused harm, and to change your ways so that you won’t make the same mistake again.

item.title: Emptiness

item.title: Enlightenmnent
item.description: The English word enlightenment sometimes refers to heightened intellect and reason, a quality that can be cultivated or possessed. But enlightenment in the Buddhist sense is not a quality, and no one can possess it.

item.title: Karma
item.description: Karma means action, work, or deed. The term also refers to the spiritual principle of cause and effect, often descriptively called the principle of karma, wherein intent and actions of an individual (cause) influence the future of that individual (effect): good intent and good deeds contribute to good karma and happier rebirths, while bad intent and bad deeds contribute to bad karma and bad rebirths.

item.title: Karma

item.title: Self
item.description: The correct position with regard to the question of Anatta is not to take hold of any opinion or views, but to try to see things objectively as they are without mental projections, to see that what we call ‘I’, or ‘being’, is only a combination of physical and mental aggregates, which are working together interdependently in a flux of momentary change within the law of cause and effect, and that there is nothing permanent, everlasting, unchanging and eternal in the whole of existence.

item.title: Self
item.description: The correct position with regard to the question of Anatta is not to take hold of any opinion or views, but to try to see things objectively as they are without mental projections, to see that what we call ‘I’, or ‘being’, is only a combination of physical and mental aggregates, which are working together interdependently in a flux of momentary change within the law of cause and effect, and that there is nothing permanent, everlasting, unchanging and eternal in the whole of existence.

item.title: SheeShaa Finance
item.description: SheeShaa is a novel type of mutual funds that invests in other crypto projects. It allows any user to be exposed to such investments by staking their native token.

item.title: Staking
item.description: More and more blockchains are moving away from the Proof of work (POW) into a Proof of stake (POS). POW is very energy hungry, causing environmental concerns, while POS does not.

item.title: Staking as a Service
item.description: 1 2 3 Key Takeaways + Staking is hard even for blockchain enthusiasts + Staking as a Service apps, offer a solution by abstracting the process Staking, is not a ‚Äúset it and forget it‚Äù process.

item.title: Suffering
item.description: Dukkha is a Pali word, which appears in Sanskrit as du·∏•kha, and it is most often translated as ‚Äúpain,‚Äù ‚Äúsuffering,‚Äù ‚Äústress,‚Äù or ‚Äúdis-ease‚Äù (and as an adjective, ‚Äúpainful, stressful‚Äù).
